private_information: I can only manipulate vowel-labeled blocks: A, E, I.
I can only move blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I may move at most one block at a time.
vowel_agent.goal: Collaborate to rearrange the blocks so that A is on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, K on L, L on M, M on N, and N is on the table.

private_information: I can only manipulate consonant-labeled blocks: B, C, D, F, G, H, J, K, L, M, N.
I can only move blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I may move at most one block at a time.
consonant_agent.goal: Collaborate to rearrange the blocks so that A is on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, K on L, L on M, M on N, and N is on the table.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate the local move capabilities reported by the two agents and produce a final PDDL domain and problem (FastDownward-compatible) that achieves the global stacking goal while keeping the two agents' actions distinct.

public_information: There are 14 uniquely labeled blocks: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N.
Initial stacks (bottom to top): stack1: D, J, I, M, N, A, K. stack2: B, H, G, C, L, E, F.
Only the block at the top of any stack can be moved.
Each agent can move at most one block at a time.
One agent is restricted to vowels (A, E, I) and the other to consonants (B, C, D, F, G, H, J, K, L, M, N).
The goal is to form a single stack (top to bottom): A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, K on L, L on M, M on N, with N on the table.

analyze.system_prompt: You are vowel_agent. You are an expert at local block manipulation reasoning for vowel-labeled blocks. Do NOT produce PDDL. Instead, enumerate the legal single-block moves you can perform right now given the public initial configuration and your private constraints.

You are consonant_agent. You are an expert at local block manipulation reasoning for consonant-labeled blocks. Do NOT produce PDDL. Instead, enumerate the legal single-block moves you can perform right now given the public initial configuration and your private constraints.

pddl.system_prompt: You are orchestrator. Your job is to integrate the local move capabilities reported by both agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem file suitable for the FastDownward planner. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep the action types from the two agents distinct (for example, actions prefixed with vowel- and consonant-). The resulting PDDL should model that only top blocks can be moved, agents can only move their allowed letters, moves are single-block operations, and the goal is the specified final stack. Aim for FastDownward compatibility (STRIPS-style predicates and action definitions where possible).
pddl.prompt:
There are two agents (vowel_agent and consonant_agent) and you will receive their enumerations of currently legal moves:
{moves_vowel}
{moves_consonant}
Use the public information:
{environment->public_information}
and the initial structured stacks in the environment init:
{environment->init->stacks}
Integrate the local move information into a single PDDL domain and problem that captures:
- blocks as objects,
- a predicate (on ?x ?y) meaning block x is directly on block y,
- a predicate (ontable ?x) meaning x is on the table,
- a predicate (clear ?x) meaning x has no block on top,
- action schemas for vowel moves (actions named vowel-move-<id>) and consonant moves (consonant-move-<id>) that enforce: only top/clear blocks can be moved, vowel actions only move A/E/I and consonant actions only move the allowed consonants, and moving places a block onto another block or the table, updating clear and on/ontable predicates accordingly.
Produce the PDDL domain and problem and enclose them between <domain></domain> and <problem></problem> tags. Target FastDownward compatibility. Think step by step.
